Circles

<a class="circle circle-[mini, medium, large] circle-[orange, blue] [two-lines]">
  <span class="circle-inner [iconified]">Your content</span>
</a>

Optional parameters

Sizes
.circle-mini .circle-medium .circle-large
Skins
.circle-orange .circle-blue

.circle-two-lines — If the text inside the circle is broken down to two lines, you should use this class to fix the centering.

.iconified — Helper class that basically sets the font family to icons so that you can easily use an icon.
warning .iconified should always be used on default and mini sizes.

How Cosm Works
Get Started


+ + Duh
E E

Boxes

Default Box

To add a box, simply follow this sample and it will automatically connect:

<article class="box [box-inset] [box-disconnected]">
<header class="box-header"></header>
<div class="box-content"></div>
</article>

.box-inset — Switches the style of the box to inset.

.box-disconnected — In case you want a box to be disconnected from the vertical line.

Boxes will inherit the width of the parent, this is to make you use grid divs and not boxes. Boxes are objects, not layout mechanisms.

Examples

h6. Heading 6

Heading with a border on bottom

Heading with sub heading

Copy

Vertical Rhythm

When having multiple text columns side by side the text should line up even when you add headings, borders, blockquotes, etc.

Composing to a vertical rhythm helps engage and guide the reader down the page, but it takes typographic discipline to do so.
It may seem like a lot of fiddly maths is involved (a few divisions and multiplications never hurt anyone) but good type setting is all about numbers, and it is this attention to detail which is the key to success.

Richard Rutter

Read more

Paragraph

Praesent id metus massa, ut blandit odio. Proin quis tortor orci. Etiam at risus et justo dignissim congue. Donec congue lacinia dui, a porttitor lectus condimentum laoreet. Nunc eu ullamcorper orci.

Emphasis

You can use the strong element or use the em element and they will be correctly formatted.

Horizontal rule

You can use <hr>, the horizontal rule, to easily create a separation with a border

Blockquotes

How to quote

To include a blockquote, wrap <blockquote> around <p> and <small> tags. Use the <footer> element to cite your source and you'll get an em dash &mdash; before it.

Example

Two things are infinite: the universe and human stupidity; and I'm not sure about the universe.

Albert Einstein

Buttons

Types

By default the buttons are outset but you can specify other types, namely .button-leveled and .button-inset

Styles

Button styles can be applied to anything with the .button applied. Typically you’ll want to apply these to only <a>, <button>, and select <input> elements.

Sizes

You can use different sizes for buttons with .button-small and .button-large.

Disabled

For buttons that are not active or are disabled by the app for one reason or another, use the disabled state. That’s .button-disabled for links and :disabled for <button> elements.

Links
Primary action Action
Buttons

Icon + Text

You also can either stick an icon to the left or use just an icon on the buttons

Important You can't use an icon with an <input> element because it doesn't support child nodes, only string values, so they should say what they do and nothing else.



Comparisions between <a>, <button> and <input> buttons

Icons

Icon Font

The icons you see are actually characters within a custom font which is embedded in the CSS with base64 encoding.

Why is it awesome?
  • You can change the size
  • You can change the color
  • You can add text-shadow
  • You can have transparency that works in IE6 unlike alpha transparent pngs.
  • You can do whatever you do with image icons
  • You'll be able to do things like add strokes to them with text-stroke or add gradients/textures with background-clip: text; once browser support is a bit deeper
  • Supported in IE (6+), iOS Devices, Android, Chrome, Firefox, Opera, Safari

Ways to use icons

Pseudo-element

recommended The simplest way of adding an icon is just by adding .icon .[icon-name] to the tag you intend to add an icon to.

Sample code
<h3 class="icon icon-activity">Title</h3>
Result

Title

Element

Whenever the pseudo-element does't suit your needs, you can use an empty <i> tag using the same classes you would in the pseudo and the icon will appear as expected.

Sample code
<i class="icon icon-activity"></i>
Result
Here's one icon and here's another
Iconified

If you just want to replace content with icons then this is the way to do it, just add .iconified to any tag and the text will be replaced with the respective icon.

Sample code
<p class="iconified">w 0 f E</p>
Result

q*fE

Forms

Default styles

All forms are given default styles to present them in a readable and scalable way. Styles are provided for text inputs, select lists, textareas, radio buttons and checkboxes, and buttons.All forms are given default styles to present them in a readable and scalable way. Styles are provided for text inputs, select lists, textareas, radio buttons and checkboxes, and buttons.

Tags

Inline Tag

Use this when you want to show a single tag.

<a class="inline-tag">

Here's a tag humidityhumidityhumidityhumidity

Tag List

<ul class="tags">
  <li><a href="#" title="View all feeds with power">power</a></li>
  <li><a href="#" title="View all feeds with watts">watts</a></li>
  <li><a href="#" title="View all feeds with arduino">arduino</a></li>
  <li><a href="#" title="View all feeds with automatic feed that has a long tag">automatic feed that has a long tag</a></li>
</ul>

Use this when you want multiple tags tag.

  • power
  • watts
  • arduino
  • automatic feed that has a long tag

Expandable Tag List

<ul id="unique-id" class="tags">
  <li><a href="#" title="View all feeds with power">power</a></li>
  <li><a href="#" title="View all feeds with watts">watts</a></li>
  <li class="view-more toggleable"><a href="#" data-cosmui="toggler" data-target"#unique-id .toggleable">+ 2</a></li>
  <li class="toggleable closed" style="display: none"><a href="#" title="View all feeds with arduino">arduino</a></li>
  <li class="toggleable closed" style="display: none"><a href="#" title="View all feeds with automatic">automatic</a></li>
  <li class="view-more toggleable closed" style="display: none"><a href="#" data-cosmui="toggler" data-target"#unique-id .toggleable">+ 2</a></li>
</ul>
  • power
  • watts
  • + 2
  • arduino
  • automatic
  • + 2

Labels

Inline Labels

<span class="label">

Call attention to or flag any phrase in your body text.

Ever needed one of those fancy New! or Important flags when writing code? Well, now you have them. Here's what's included by default:

Label Result
<span class="label">Default</span> Default
<span class="label label-success">New</span> New
<span class="label label-warning">Warning</span> Warning
<span class="label label-important">Important</span> Important
<span class="label label-notice">Notice</span> Notice

Tables

<table> <thead> <tbody> <tr> <th> <td> <colspan> <caption>

Tables are great—for a lot of things. Great tables, however, need a bit of markup love to be useful, scalable, and readable (at the code level). Here are a few tips to help.

Always wrap your column headers in a <thead> such that hierarchy is <thead> > <tr> > <th>.

Similar to the column headers, all your table’s body content should be wrapped in a <tbody> so your hierarchy is <tbody> > <tr> > <td>.

Default Table

All tables will be automatically styled with only the essential borders to ensure readability and maintain structure. No need to add extra classes or attributes.

# First Name Last Name Language
1 Some One English
2 Joe Sixpack English
3 Stu Dent Code

Condensed Table

For tables that require more data in tighter spaces, use the .condensed class that cuts padding in half. It can also be used in conjunction with borders and zebra-stripes, just like the default table styles. This table style will mess up the vertical rhythm though.

# First Name Last Name Language
1 Some One English
2 Joe Sixpack English
3 Stu Dent Code

Bordered Table

Make your tables with .bordered look just a wee bit sleeker by rounding their corners and adding borders on all sides.

# First Name Last Name Language
1 Some One English
2 Joe Sixpack English
3 Stu Dent Code

Zebra-striped Table

Get a little fancyby adding zebra-striping — just add the .zebra-striped class.

# First Name Last Name Language
1 Some One English
2 Joe Sixpack English
3 Stu Dent Code
span 4 columns
span 2 columns span 2 columns
